questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is the most common, preventable cause of mental retardation?
questions.explanation:
Congenital hypothyroidism is the most common preventable cause of mental retardation which 
results from a deficient production of thyroid hormone. It is more common among girls and the 
prevalence is about 1:3000 to 1:4000 births. Down's syndrome is the most common overall cause of mental retardation, followed by Fragile X 
syndrome, which mainly affects boys. 585

questions.question:
Question 2: In a 4-month old, term infant with open posterior fontanelle and hypotonia, you suspect 
congenital hypothyroidism and send thyroid studies. Which of the following is the most 
common cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Thyroid dysgenesis is the most common cause of permanent congenital hypothyroidism (80–85% 
of cases) > dyshormonogenesis (15%). Dysgenesis may involve ectopy, agenesis (absence) or hypoplasia (underdevelopment) of the 
thyroid gland. Dyshormonogenesis results from a defect in any of the steps in thyroid hormone 
biosynthesis. *TSH - thyroid-stimulating hormone; TRH - thyroid-releasing hormone Acquired hypothyroidism can be caused by iodine deficiency, thyroiditis, radiation, histiocytosis, 
and drugs. The most common cause of acquired hypothyroidism is autoimmune thyroiditis 
(Hashimoto's). Note: Mutation in PAX-8 gene is associated with congenital hypothyroidism and genitourinary 
abnormalities such as renal agenesis. 586

questions.question:
Question 3: You are called to see a 3-day-old, term neonate, who has not passed meconium yet. On 
clinical examination, there is generalized hypotonia and the abdomen is slightly distended 
without any evidence of ascites or hepatosplenomegaly. Incidentally, you also note a palpable 
goitre in this baby. Laboratory investigations reveal low T4 and elevated TSH levels. Which of 
the following is the most likely cause for this child's condition?
questions.explanation:
A history of decreased activity and late passage of meconium, associated with low T4 and high 
TSH is suggestive of primary hypothyroidism. In an infant with a palpable goitre, the likely 
diagnosis is congenital hypothyroidism secondary to thyroid dyshormonogenesis. The most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism is thyroid dysgenesis but it is not 
associated with goitre. Thyroid dyshormonogenesis results from the deficiency of one or more 
enzymes involved in thyroid hormone synthesis/secretion. Congenital hypothyroidism can be: Goitrous(Palpable goitre) 
Non-goitrous(No palpable goi 
tre) Thyroid dyshormonogenesisI

questions.question:
Question 4: 579 
Sold by @itachibot At how many weeks of gestation does thyroxine secretion begin in a fetus?
questions.explanation:
Thyroxine secretion begins in the fetus at 12 weeks of gestation. 587 
Sold by @itachibot The fetal thyroid arises from an outpouching of the foregut at the base of the tongue (foramen 
cecum). It migrates to its normal location over the thyroid cartilage by 8-10 wk of gestation. The 
bilobed shape of the thyroid is recognized by 7 weeks of gestation.

questions.question:
Question 5: An anxious mother has brought a 4-month-old baby with complaints that the baby is not 
feeding well and is excessively sleepy all the time. Clinical examination reveals jaundice and 
hypotonia. His picture is provided below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above picture shows a child with a protuberant abdomen, umbilical hernia, macroglossia, and 
edematous facies. Also, the infant is sluggish, has jaundice, feeding difficulties, and hypotonia, all 
of which suggests a diagnosis of congenital hypothyroidism. Clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism: • Prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia- early sign (it is due to delayed maturation of 
glucuronide conjugation) • Constipation- usually does not respond to treatment • Wide open anterior and posterior fontanelles (>0.5 cm) and cranial sutures • Developmental delay, delayed bone growth, delayed dentition • Cardiovascular- slow pulse rate, cardiomegaly, asymptomatic pericardial effusion, edema • Respiratory- macroglossia, feeding difficulties, choking spells, respiratory difficulties • Haematological- macrocytic anaemia refractory to treatment with haematinics • Nervous system- hypothermia, hypotonia, slow relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, sluggishness, 
and somnolence

questions.question:
Question 6: A newborn with abnormal neonatal screening tests was diagnosed with Pendred syndrome. 
Which of the following is not a feature of this syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Sensorineural hearing loss is present in Pendred syndrome; not conductive hearing loss. Pendred syndrome is an autosomal-recessive disorder, caused by a mutation in the gene SLC26A4 
on chromosome 7, which codes for pendrin, a chloride–iodide transport protein common to the 
thyroid gland and the cochlea. Clinical features include sensorineural hearing loss and goitre with hypothyroidism. It is the most 
common cause of syndromic deafness. The biochemical reason for hypothyroidism in patients 
with Pendred syndrome is impaired iodide organification (resulting from a mutation in the 
Pendrin gene).

questions.question:
Question 7: A 9-day-old infant has elevated TSH level and low T4 level on newborn screening. If this 
condition is left untreated, which of the following is most likely to be seen in this infant in the 
first few months of life?
questions.explanation:
Elevated TSH levels and low T4 levels in a 9-day-old infant are suggestive of congenital 
hypothyroidism. Prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia is an early sign of congenital 
hypothyroidism. It is due to delayed maturation of the hepatic glucuronide conjugation system. Hyperreflexia, hyperirritability and diarrhoea are seen in hyperthyroidism; not hypothyroidism. 588 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Kocher–Debré–Sémélaigne syndrome: The muscles are usually hypotonic in congenital 
hypothyroidism. Rarely, hypothyroidism in infancy can be characterized by generalized muscular 
pseudohypertrophy, myxoedema, short stature and cretinism. Affected older children can have an 
athletic appearance. Boys are more prone to the development of the syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 8: During a rural health camp, a father brings a dull-looking baby with macroglossia and an 
umbilical hernia. On enquiry, you find out that the parents were told about a thyroid problem 
in the child at birth, for which they did not pursue any treatment. Which of the following is 
least likely to be found in children with the given condition?
questions.explanation:
A dull-looking face with macroglossia, and umbilical hernia in a child with a thyroid disorder are 
all indicative of congenital hypothyroidism. Craniosynostosis is not seen in neonatal 
hypothyroidism. It is seen in hyperthyroidism. Craniosynostosis refers to the premature fusion of sutures and closure of fontanelles and often 
results in abnormal, triangular facies. In congenital hypothyroidism, there is delayed closure of 
the fontanelles. Palpable goitre, though not common, can be seen in cases of untreated thyroid 
dyshormonogenesis.

questions.question:
Question 9: As part of a quality improvement project undertaken by the maternal and child health 
services, you are evaluating the current practice of newborn screening and detection rates of 
hypothyroidism in various community health centres. Which of the following statements is 
false?

options.a: Simultaneous measurement of T4 and TSH levels is the ideal method.
options.b: The sample is obtained by heel-prick between 1-5 days of life using dried blood spot.
options.c: Newborn screening always detects the affected twin in same-sex twins.
options.d: Primary TSH, with back up T4 is the most common strategy used.

questions.explanation:
Newborn screening can fail to detect the affected twin with hypothyroidism. Discordance for thyroid dysgenesis is the rule in monozygotic twins. The transfusion of euthyroid 
blood from the unaffected twin normalizes the serum levels of T4 and TSH in the affected twin, 
resulting in delayed or missed diagnoses. Therefore, a second sample for congenital 
hypothyroidism screening at 14 days of age should be considered in monozygotic twins. Neonatal thyroid screening strategies: • Primarily TSH, backup T4; T4 is measured if TSH level is >20 mU/L • Primarily T4, backup TSH: TSH is measured only if T4 level is low • Concomitant T4 and TSH; it is the most sensitive method Note: the sample is obtained after 24-48 hours, to minimize the false elevation of TSH values due 
to normal post-delivery neonatal TSH surge.

questions.question:
Question 10: As an intern posted in paediatrics, you are asked to interpret the results of a heel prick test 
that you performed on a newborn. Which of the following results is suggestive of primary 
hypothyroidism?

options.a: Low T4 level and low TSH level
options.b: Low T4 level and high TSH level
options.c: High T4 level and low TSH level
options.d: High T4 level and high TSH level

questions.explanation:
Low T4 and high TSH levels indicate primary hypothyroidism. Blood specimen for neonatal thyroid screening is obtained by heel prick between 1 and 5 days of 
life. Levothyroxine therapy is started immediately after diagnosis, at 10 to 15 µg/kg per day. 589

questions.question:
Question 11: The image given below depicts an x-ray of the knee in a term baby. Which among the 
following conditions is associated with it?
questions.explanation:
The deformity shown in the X-ray image is the absence of distal femoral epiphysis, which is a 
typical radiological feature of congenital hypothyroidism. X- ray findings in hypothyroidism • Absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphyses at birth. • Punctate epiphyseal dysgenesis (multiple foci of ossification) • Deformity or beaking of the 12th thoracic or 1st or 2nd lumbar vertebra • X-ray image of the skull shows large fontanels and wide sutures; wormian (intrasutural) bones; 
and, often, an enlarged and round sella turcica. Image below: The infant on the left with congenital hypothyroidism demonstrates the absence of 
the distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphyses, while in the normal infant on the right the distal 
femoral epiphysis is present: 590 
Sold by @itachibot The image below shows small upper femoral epiphyses: The image below shows enlarged sella turcica and wormian bones (intrasutural):

questions.question:
Question 12: Ayesha is a 9th standard girl who presented with a neck swelling, which began more than a 
year ago. Her mother says she is embarrassed about it and always covers her neck with a 582 
Sold by @itachibot shawl when she goes to school. Her menstrual cycles have also become irregular as of late. 
Blood tests reveal slightly elevated TSH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase 
antibodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies (TPO-Abs) and elevated thyroid-stimulating 
hormone (TSH) level in a child with a goitre is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic (Hashimoto) 
thyroiditis. Chronic lymphocytic (Hashimoto) thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease. Clinical presentation can 
include goitre, growth retardation, and other features of hypothyroidism. The thyroid is diffusely 
enlarged, firm, and non-tender. 591 
Sold by @itachibot TSH is moderately elevated and TPO-Abs and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies (anti-Tg Abs) can be 
detected. The image given below shows goitre due to Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

questions.question:
Question 13: A lady, with a history of a thyroid disorder and three prior abortions, delivered a female 
neonate prematurely at 34 weeks of gestation. In the newborn infant, tachycardia, irritability, 
and prominent eyes were noted and neonatal hyperthyroidism was suspected. Which of the 
following statements is false about the condition?

options.a: Maternal Graves' disease is the most common cause of neonatal hyperthyroidism
options.b: It results from the transplacental passage of maternal stimulatory TSH receptor antibody
options.c: Microcephaly and frontal bossing with triangular facies are common clinical findings
options.d: Neonatal hyperthyroidism occurs in most infants born to mothers with a history of Graves’

questions.explanation:
Neonatal hyperthyroidism occurs in only about 2% of infants born to mothers with a history of 
Graves’ disease. But maternal Graves' disease is by far the most common cause of neonatal 
hyperthyroidism. Neonatal hyperthyroidism (due to Grave's) results from the transplacental passage of maternal 
stimulatory thyrotropin/TSH receptor antibody (TSHR-Ab). Clinical features are as follows: • Low birth weight (IUGR) • Premature birth • Microcephaly • Frontal bossing and triangular facies • Warm, moist skin • Irritability, hyperactivity, restlessness, poor sleep • Tachycardia Note: TSHR-Ab (TSH-R-stimulating antibodies) is another name for TSH-R-stimulating 
immunoglobulins (TSI). 592 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A pregnant woman with a past history of Grave's disease has currently completed 36 weeks of 
gestation. She underwent partial thyroidectomy 10 years back and has remained euthyroid 
since then. The previous child had craniosynostosis. Which of the following antibodies is 
most likely to be detected, if a cord blood sampling is done at delivery?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with a history of Graves' disease in the mother and craniosynostosis 
(neonatal Graves') in the previous child suggests that the fetus is at increased risk of neonatal 
Grave's disease. Thus, the antibody likely to be found at birth in the cord blood sampling is the 
TSH receptor stimulating antibody (TRSAb). Neonatal Graves is caused by the transplacental passage of TRSAbs from a mother with a history 
of Graves' disease. The mothers can have • Active Graves' disease • Graves' in remission • Prior history of Graves' treated with radioactive ablation or thyroidectomy TSRAbs bind to the receptor for TSH and stimulate cyclic AMP, leading to thyroid hyperplasia 
and unregulated overproduction of thyroid hormone.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 4-year-old girl, a known case of celiac disease, presented to the pediatric endocrine clinic 
with a history of neck swelling, tremor, and weight loss. On evaluation, she was found to have 583 
Sold by @itachibot Graves’ disease. Other conditions that need to be screened in this patient include all of the 
following except  
.
questions.explanation: Type 2 Diabetes mellitus is not associated with Grave's disease. Conditions associated with Grave's disease (autoimmune diseases): • Diabetes mellitus type 1 • Pernicious anaemia • Celiac disease • Vitiligo • Addison disease • Alopecia areata • Myasthenia gravis

questions.question:
Question 16: An 11-year-old girl was brought by her parents with complaints of weight loss, increased 
appetite, and a decline in scholastic performance. Following investigations, a diagnosis of 
Grave’s disease is made. Which of the following is the drug of choice for initial therapy?
questions.explanation:
Methimazole is the initial drug of choice for treating Grave's disease (hyperthyroidism) in 
children. Option A: Propylthiouracil is not recommended in children because it is associated with fatal 
hepatotoxicity. Option C: Radioactive iodine is not preferred as the first-line treatment in hyperthyroidism for 
children. Option D: Levothyroxine is used to treat hypothyroidism. 593 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 17: Your unit chief has asked you to present the case of a teenager, who was admitted for 
evaluation of mental retardation, deaf-mutism and a gait disturbance. He also has a 
significant patellar clonus. On general exam, you note a goitre but according to lab reports, he 
is apparently euthyroid. His pubertal development has also been normal. The most likely 
diagnosis is  
.
questions.explanation:
The clinical presentation of a euthyroid patient with goitre as well as mental retardation, 
deaf-mutism, and normal pubertal development points towards neurological endemic cretinism. Endemic cretinism includes 2 different, but overlapping, syndromes: neurologic type and 
myxedematous type. It is essentially the same disorder, phenotypically modified by the length and 
severity of postnatal hypothyroidism. Neurological manifestations are interpreted as reflecting the 
effects of maternal and fetal hypothyroxinemia, secondary to severe iodine deficiency, on the 
developing nervous system. Both neurologic and myxedematous type can manifest neurologic 
symptoms. Although neurological cretins are euthyroid, linear growth arrest lines in the long bones are often 
demonstrated radiologically, suggesting previous hypothyroidism. Option B: Graves disease includes a triad of hyperthyroidism with goitre, ophthalmopathy, and 
dermopathy (no mental retardation, deafness, or pyramidal signs). Option C: Pendred Syndrome is caused by a mutation in chloride–iodide transporter in thyroid 
and cochlea resulting in euthyroid/hypothyroid goitre and sensorineural hearing loss (pyramidal 
signs like clonus are not seen).

questions.question:
Question 18: During a health outreach program in Sikkim, you come across 3 children from the same 
family, with goiter. Endemic cretinism was suspected. Which of the following can be a 
manifestation of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Strabismus and spastic diplegias are among the manifestations of the neurological type of 
endemic cretinism. Cretinism is a condition characterized by irreversible abnormalities in intellectual 
development. Endemic cretinism occurs due to the nutritional deficiency of iodine. It can be 
neurological cretinism or myxedematous cretinism. It is associated with severe, irreversible 
mental retardation. 594 
Sold by @itachibot Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia and Related Disorders
